metadata.chief_complaint: routine well-child visit with vaccine questions

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good morning! I'm Dr. Martinez. How are you and little Emma doing today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Hi, we're okay. She's been a little fussy this morning, but I think she's just tired.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's completely normal for a 12-month-old. Let's start by going over how she's been doing since her 9-month visit. Any concerns?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Well, I have some questions about her vaccines today. I've been reading things online and I'm just... worried.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm glad you brought that up. It's natural to have questions as a first-time mom. Let's talk about that after we go through her development. How's her eating?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's eating table foods now, finger foods. She loves bananas and cheerios. She's still nursing about 4 times a day.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That sounds perfect for her age. How about sleep? Is she sleeping through the night?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Most nights, yes. She goes down around 7 and sleeps until about 6. Sometimes she wakes up once.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Excellent. And developmentally, is she pulling herself up to stand? Walking along furniture?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes! She's cruising all around the coffee table. She took a couple steps by herself last week but hasn't done it again.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's wonderful! First steps are so exciting. Is she saying any words besides mama and dada?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She says 'bye bye' and waves. And she says something that sounds like 'book' when we read to her.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Perfect language development for 12 months. Now let me examine her. [examining] She looks great - good color, alert and interactive.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She doesn't like being on the exam table. Should I hold her?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's fine, you can hold her for most of this. [examining] Her ears look clear, throat looks good. Heart and lungs sound normal.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: That's good to hear. So about the vaccines... I read that some parents space them out?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I understand your concern. The CDC schedule is designed to protect children when they're most vulnerable. What specifically worries you?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I guess I'm worried about giving her too much at once. And I read about autism... I know you probably think I'm being silly.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You're not being silly at all. Multiple large studies have shown no link between vaccines and autism. The MMR vaccine is very safe.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: But couldn't we just wait a few more months? She's not in daycare yet.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I understand wanting to protect her, but measles can be serious even in healthy children. The immunity from nursing has worn off by now.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I didn't know that. So she's not protected anymore?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Exactly. That's why we give the MMR at 12 months. Would you like me to give you some reliable resources to read about vaccine safety?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes, that would be helpful. I want to do what's best for her. Maybe we could do just the MMR today and come back for the others?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a reasonable compromise. We can do the MMR today and schedule the varicella and Hib vaccines for next month if that makes you more comfortable.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay, yes. I think that would help me feel better about it. Thank you for being patient with me.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Of course. Being a new mom comes with so many decisions. You're doing a great job. Emma is thriving.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you. When should we come back for her 15-month checkup?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: In about 3 months. The nurse will give you the shot today and schedule both appointments. Any other questions before we finish up?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, I think we're good. Thank you for answering all my questions. Come on Emma, time for your shot.
